results.name: Arcades and AI
results.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

key_work.title: Imagine a World...
key_work.brief_description:
Science fiction doesn’t just predict the future – it helps us imagine what’s possible. Since Fritz Lang’s Metropolis (1927), science fiction has explored how technology, society and humanity might change. The genre gives us visions of the future while asking questions about ethics, identity and equality.

In Things to Come (1936) and Alphaville (1965), we see dreams of perfect worlds clashing with harsh realities, while Big Hero Six (2014) offers a hopeful take on technology being used for good. Movies like Blade Runner (1982) and Ghost in the Shell (1995) explore the line between human and machine, raising questions about identity and what it means to be alive. Even in the chaotic world of Terminator 2 (1991) or the frosted dystopia of Snowpiercer (2013), these films suggest we have the power to change the future.

Screen culture dares us to dream of what we can achieve, challenging us to make sure that progress brings hope, inclusion, and a future where humanity can thrive alongside technology.

The AI voice in this visual essay echoes the sensationalist voice-overs common on early sci-fi trailers, while the voice distortion pays tribute to the genre’s often-villainous android characters like HAL 9000 (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Ava in Ex Machina (2014).

end.title: Ex Machina
end.creator_credit: Allon Reich, Andrew Macdonald and Andrew MacDonald
end.brief_description: A young coder wins a competition to spend a week at a private mountain retreat belonging to the world’s largest internet company’s reclusive CEO. But when he arrives, Caleb has to participate in an experiment involving the world’s first true AI.

constellations_other.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_other.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

constellations_other.name: Robots, robots everywhere
constellations_other.description: Steampunk aesthetics, malevolent AI and cybernetic cops push the frontiers of imagination in this Constellation inspired by Dishonored 2.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

links.description: Videogames and Us features the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, who created the imitation game, now known as the Turing Test, to determine if computers could behave like humans. It’s an early basis for AI – something explored in Ex Machina.

constellations_other.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

constellations_other.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_other.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

links.description: While Pris is one of the most iconic dangerous and highly sexualised AI androids in movies, the trope goes right back to the beginning of cinema with Fritz Lang’s groundbreaking Metropolis featuring Maria, who appears as a typical robot and a sensual woman.

end.title: Computer Space
end.brief_description: Computer Space is a video arcade game released in 1971 by Nutting Associates. Created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, who would both later found Atari, Inc., it is generally accepted that it was the world’s first commercially sold coin-operated video game of any kind.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

links.description: In 1962, MIT students made a computer game called Spacewar! from data stored on punched paper tape. When Atari founder Nolan Bushnell saw the two ships battling across a digitised starfield, he was inspired to develop and release Atari’s first arcade machine, Computer Space.

start.title: Computer Space
start.brief_description: Computer Space is a video arcade game released in 1971 by Nutting Associates. Created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, who would both later found Atari, Inc., it is generally accepted that it was the world’s first commercially sold coin-operated video game of any kind.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots

end.title: Imagine a World...
end.brief_description:
Science fiction doesn’t just predict the future – it helps us imagine what’s possible. Since Fritz Lang’s Metropolis (1927), science fiction has explored how technology, society and humanity might change. The genre gives us visions of the future while asking questions about ethics, identity and equality.

In Things to Come (1936) and Alphaville (1965), we see dreams of perfect worlds clashing with harsh realities, while Big Hero Six (2014) offers a hopeful take on technology being used for good. Movies like Blade Runner (1982) and Ghost in the Shell (1995) explore the line between human and machine, raising questions about identity and what it means to be alive. Even in the chaotic world of Terminator 2 (1991) or the frosted dystopia of Snowpiercer (2013), these films suggest we have the power to change the future.

Screen culture dares us to dream of what we can achieve, challenging us to make sure that progress brings hope, inclusion, and a future where humanity can thrive alongside technology.

The AI voice in this visual essay echoes the sensationalist voice-overs common on early sci-fi trailers, while the voice distortion pays tribute to the genre’s often-villainous android characters like HAL 9000 (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Ava in Ex Machina (2014).

links.description: The AI-generated voiceover used in The Futures & Other Fictions video essay Imagine a world pays homage to the villainous AI androids like Ava in Ex Machina.

end.title: Scott no friends
end.creator_credit: Patrick Gorman
end.brief_description:
This responsive display presents the moment, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

PM Scott Morrison got the cold shoulder at the G20 conference in Rome. His 11th-hour plan for net-zero emissions by 2050 was criticised at home and abroad for lacking any real details, except faith that uninvented tech might save the day, and the French president labelled him a liar over the submarine fiasco. Other world leaders made their displeasure to the government’s handling of recent issues known by collectively shunning the maskless Morrison during a group photo.

end.title: Puberty Blues
end.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford
end.brief_description: Before American teen movies swamped Australia’s cinemas from the mid-1980s onwards, Puberty Blues (1981) captivated audiences with its honest and raw depiction of Australian adolescence. Not only did it explore teen social hierarchies, relationships, peer pressure and toxic machismo, it highlighted the power of female friendship and proved that chicks do surf. Based on the semi-autobiographical novel by Kathy Lette and Gabrielle Carey, the film’s authenticity can be traced to their own experience growing up on Sydney’s Cronulla beaches. Featuring a memorable soundtrack with contributions from Split Enz and trash-talking dialogue that popularised getting “dropped” and complaining about “molls”, Puberty Blues captures a unique slice of Australiana.

constellations_primary.name: Teenage dreams
constellations_primary.description: Puberty Blues realistically represents the trials and tribulations of Australian adolescence. Since then a diverse range of originals and remakes offer new perspectives on teen dreams.

links.description: Puberty Blues is based on Australia’s first coming-of-age novel written by Gabrielle Carey and Kathy Lette. It follows two teenage girls over a Sydney summer and instead of putting another Australian myth on a pedestal, it reveals the male chauvinism of the surfie subculture.

end.title: Figurines (Collectibles)
end.brief_description: Long after the credits roll on a film or television series, the characters might live on in our hearts and minds. They can also live on physically, in our homes and offices, as collectibles that pay homage to our passions. That can be in the form of Felix The Cat, a black and white cartoon from the silent film era, or One-Punch Man, a viral hero from a cult Japanese web comic turned anime. Figurines sometimes become more famous that the original screen character, like Margot Robbie’s Harley Quinn from Suicide Squad (2016) who became a pop cultural icon thanks to her own spin-off film Birds of Prey.

end.title: Deconstructed TV
end.brief_description: It’s hard to imagine, but television wasn’t always a 24/7/365 affair. TV stations used to stop broadcasting late at night when they ran out of programming. When off the air, they would commonly display a test pattern until the broadcast schedule resumed in the morning. Now television can be consumed free-to-air or whenever you want it thanks to on-demand and streaming services. This deconstructed TV was a National brand model, the kind of appliance mass produced in the 1970s. Today families are less likely to gather around a single TV set, instead favouring their own fractured shards of screen content

links.description: News and variety TV shows have been a staple of the Australian small screen since its arrival in the 1950s. The longest-running Australian news program is Four Corners, which has been running since 1961 and features award-winning investigations and documentaries.

key_work.title: The Power of Love
key_work.creator_credit: Harry K. Fairall and Nat G. Deverich
key_work.brief_description: The first feature 3D motion picture screened for a commercial audience was The Power of Love (1922), which used the red-and-green anaglyph system that most people associate with 3D. Audiences looked through red-and-green glasses at two film strips, recorded and projected in each colour.

key_work.title: Inspired design and costume sketches
key_work.brief_description: Costume designers don’t always rely on sketches of their creations. True History of the Kelly Gang designer Alice Babidge sketches to distil references, while Judy & Punch designer Edie Kurzer gets more inspiration from objects.

end.title: Judy & Punch
end.creator_credit: Edie Kurzer, Danny Gabai, Michele Bennett, Nash Edgerton, Create NSW, Pariah Productions, Screen Australia, Soundfirm, VICE Media and Mirrah Foulkes
end.brief_description: In the anarchic town of Seaside, nowhere near the sea, puppeteers Judy and Punch are trying to resurrect their marionette show. The show is a hit due to Judy’s superior puppeteering but Punch’s driving ambition and penchant for whisky lead to an inevitable tragedy that Judy must avenge.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

end.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Some like it hot
constellations_other.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

end.title: Sweet Country
end.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
end.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Because of the size of the Australian film and TV industry, production crew often find themselves working together. This happened to costume designer Heather Wallace and set decorator Jennifer Drake, who worked together on both of these films.

start.title: Inspired design and costume sketches
start.brief_description: Costume designers don’t always rely on sketches of their creations. True History of the Kelly Gang designer Alice Babidge sketches to distil references, while Judy & Punch designer Edie Kurzer gets more inspiration from objects.

constellations_primary.name: Inspired design and costume sketches

end.title: True History of the Kelly Gang
end.creator_credit: Alice Babidge, Brad Feinstein, Hal Vogel and Liz Watts
end.brief_description: True History of the Kelly Gang is a 2019 British-Australian biographical western film based on the exploits of Australia’s famous outlaw, Ned Kelly. It’s directed by Justin Kurzel, from a screenplay by Shaun Grant, based upon the 2000 novel of the same name by Peter Carey.

constellations_primary.name: The Australian industry
constellations_primary.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_primary.name: Alice Babidge and True History of the Kelly Gang
constellations_primary.description: An acclaimed set, costume, and production designer in the world of theatre, Alice Babidge has most recently been working in film including Justin Kurzel features Snowtown and True History Of The Kelly Gang.

constellations_other.name: Pink, Pose, punk, Pilgrim
constellations_other.description: Alice Babidge's costume design for True History of the Kelly Gang sees the iconic foursome and their accomplices in dresses, a gender-expansive stance that connects to other rebellious outlooks on the world.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”.

start.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock
start.creator_credit: Antonia Barnard and Brett Popplewell
start.brief_description: Valentine’s Day, 1900. Three schoolgirls and their governess mysteriously disappear in Hanging Rock, Australia, without a trace.

constellations_other.name: Clothing, country, character
constellations_other.description: Edie Kurzer's costume design work on Judy & Punch and Picnic at Hanging Rock is part of a larger trend in Australian films and TV series.

constellations_other.name: Teenage dreams
constellations_other.description: Puberty Blues realistically represents the trials and tribulations of Australian adolescence. Since then a diverse range of originals and remakes offer new perspectives on teen dreams.

end.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock purple fete and mourning dress design materials
end.creator_credit: Edie Kurzer
end.brief_description: Mrs Appleyard’s purple fete outfit was fabricated from scratch, while the reference materials illustrate some of the details that went into Edie Kurzer’s garment design. The costume sketch and mood board show how Kurzer gathered a body of historical reference points while crafting the original garments.

key_work.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
key_work.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

results.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
results.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

key_work.title: Magic lantern projectors
key_work.brief_description: Magic lanterns were made in all shapes and sizes from materials as diverse as biscuit tins and brass to mahogany and nickel. They were even mass-produced as children’s toys in the 19th century.

links.description: Fairytales and myths (like Prince Achmed, which is based on stories from One Thousand and One Nights) have long inspired filmmakers, including Alice Guy Blache, who made the world’s first narrative film based on the Cabbage Patch Fairy.

start.title: The Cabbage-Patch Fairy
start.creator_credit: Gaumont and Alice Guy-Blaché
start.brief_description: La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage-Patch Fairy) is considered the first fictional film with a scripted narrative. It was created by trailblazing French filmmaker Alice Guy-Blaché, who returned to the story numerous time early in her career.

end.title: Round the twist: the cabbage patch fib
end.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Antonia Barnard, Australian Children's Television Foundation and Paul Jennings
end.brief_description: Believing that babies grow in the cabbage patch, Bronson actually finds one there. But he soon discovers that the responsibilities of parenthood have their drawbacks.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

links.description: Beloved Australian children’s show Round the Twist often featured fantastical stories told in a modern Australian setting. Some, like the episode ‘The Cabbage Patch Fib’, were based on fairy tales. In this episode, Ronson finds a baby and learns how hard parenting can be.

start.title: Little Red Riding Hood
start.creator_credit: Walt Disney, Laugh-O-Gram Films and Charles Parrault
start.brief_description: Disney’s 1922 animated version of Little Red Riding Hood was one of the first moving image works of the famous cautionary tale not to talk to strangers.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors

end.title: The Path
end.brief_description: The Path is a psychological horror art game developed by Tale of Tales which is inspired by the Little Red Riding Hood fairytale. The player can choose six different sisters to run errands but the wolf always lies in wait.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors

links.description: Little Red Riding Hood doesn’t only turn up on cinema screens, but also game consoles. The beloved fairytale was adapted into a psychological horror drama by developers Tale of Tales called The Path, where players are meant to take the wrong turn.

start.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
start.creator_credit: Lotte Reiniger
start.brief_description: While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed precedes the Disney film by over a decade.

constellations_primary.name: Shadowplay and spookiness

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors

constellations_other.name: Storytelling through shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play has brought stories to life for thousands of years and is still used today.

end.title: Aladdin
end.creator_credit: John Musker, Ron Clements, Walt Disney Animation Studios, Walt Disney Pictures, R.S. vander Wende, Ted Elliott, Terry Rossio, Brian Pimental, Burny Mattinson, Chris Sanders, Daan Jippes, Darrell Rooney, David Scott Smith, Francis Glebas, James Fujii, Kevin Harkey, Kevin Lima, Kirk Hanson, Larry Leker, Patrick A. Ventura, Rebecca Reese, Roger Allers and Sue C. Nichols
end.brief_description: Princess Jasmine grows tired of being forced to remain in the palace, so she sneaks out into the marketplace, in disguise, where she meets street-urchin Aladdin. The couple falls in love, although Jasmine may only marry a prince. After being thrown in jail, Aladdin becomes embroiled in a plot to find a mysterious lamp, with which the evil Jafar hopes to rule the land.

constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

links.description: One of the stories in One Thousand and One Nights that Prince Achmed incorporated is Aladdin, which Disney famously turned into a beloved animated feature in 1992.

results.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
results.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

key_work.title: Magic lantern slides
key_work.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth. When photography arrived in the 1840s, photos started appearing on lantern slides.

end.title: Moon landing
end.brief_description: On 21 July 1969, Neil Armstrong and Edwin ‘Buzz’ Aldrin became the first people to walk on the Moon. Through a global satellite network, this historic event was broadcast around the world and united an estimated 600 million people in a single moment.

links.description: It would be over 65 years until humans actually did land on the Moon’s surface, when the Apollo 11 spacecraft touched down and united the world with an estimated 500 million people watching the moment Buzz Aldrin took one giant leap for mankind.

end.title: First still of Black Hole
end.brief_description: The Event Horizon Telescope—a planet-scale array of ground-based radio telescopes—has obtained the first image of a supermassive black hole and its shadow. The image, taken in 2019, reveals the central black hole of Messier 87, a massive galaxy in the Virgo cluster.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

constellations_other.name: A brief history of black holes on-screen
constellations_other.description: In 1916, Albert Einstein predicted black holes through his theory of general relativity. That mix of science and imagination can be seen in Marshmallow Laser Feast’s Distortions in Spacetime. These other works are fascinated by these cosmic giants and represent an evolution in computer graphics and VFX.

links.description: In 2019, the first-ever image of a black hole 55 million light-years away was captured by Katie Bouman and the Event Horizon Telescope, an astronomical event that captured imaginations like the first moon landing.

end.title: Solaris
end.creator_credit: Viacheslav Tarasov
end.brief_description: A psychologist is sent to a space station orbiting a planet called Solaris to investigate the death of a doctor and the mental problems of cosmonauts on the station. He soon discovers that the water on the planet brings out repressed memories and obsessions.

constellations_other.name: Returning to Solaris
constellations_other.description: Stanislaw Lem’s novel Solaris (1961) tells the haunting story of a space research expedition’s encounter with a sentient ocean planet. Here we look at how different artists have responded to, remixed and referenced Solaris over film, television, and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes

links.description: There are many references to Andrei Tarkovsky’s work throughout Mass Effect, including planetary bodies that mirror the oceanic world of Solaris and the name of the largest armour corporation.

end.creator_credit: Stanley Kubrick and Victor Lyndon
end.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 1968
end.brief_description: Humanity finds a mysterious object buried beneath the lunar surface and sets off to find its origins with the help of HAL 9000, the world’s most advanced super computer, in Stanley Kubrick’s masterpiece, which pushed cinematic narratives and special effects.

constellations_other.name: Sounds unreal
constellations_other.description: A history of syncing sound effects, a craft known as Foley in the USA and bootstepping in the UK.

constellations_other.name: Future visions
constellations_other.description: Entities is a time-based data visualisation of visitors collecting objects and exploring Constellations. These actions are translated into graphical forms to show what’s being collected, as well as highlighting Constellations that share connections.

constellations_other.name: Kaleidoscopic colour: Chromotrope
constellations_other.description: A focus on distinctive and innovative examples of pattern, colour and movement.

constellations_other.name: Auteurs, influence and inspiration
constellations_other.description: A tradition of influence and inspiration beginning with Eisenstein.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

constellations_other.name: Sublime light and special effects
constellations_other.description: Explore 19th-century artist John Martin’s surprising influence on science fiction and fantasy films of the 20th century, from Jason and the Argonauts to the Lord of the Rings and the Evil Dead franchises.

links.description: Tarkovsky’s Solaris was partly inspired by his disdain for other speculative fiction films, in particular Stanley Kubrick’s 2001, which he described as ‘phony on many levels’ and ‘a lifeless schema with only pretensions to truth’.

results.name: The world's end

start.title: The Leftovers
start.creator_credit: Carly Wray, John Blair, Warner Bros. Television and John Paino
start.brief_description: When 2% of the world’s population abruptly disappears without explanation, the world struggles to understand just what they’re supposed to do about it. The drama series The Leftovers is the story of the people who didn’t make the cut.

links.description: The biblical rapture story hasn’t only inspired TV showrunners, but videogame developers too. The Chinese Room’s Everbody’s Gone to the Rapture lets players explore a small town where everyone has also mysteriously disappeared.

constellations_other.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

links.description: Motion graphics studio Antibody created the mind-bending mix of divinity and depravity that features in the American Gods title sequence. They also applied their otherworldly aesthetic to cosmological horror show Lovecraft Country, which reimagines HP Lovecraft’s monsters to reframe race relations in 1950s America.

start.title: Watchmen
start.creator_credit: John Blair, Karen Wacker, Warner Bros. Television and White Rabbit
start.brief_description: Set in an alternate history where superheroes are treated as outlaws, Watchmen embraces the nostalgia of the original groundbreaking graphic novel while attempting to break new ground of its own.

end.title: The Leftovers
end.creator_credit: Carly Wray, John Blair, Warner Bros. Television and John Paino
end.brief_description: When 2% of the world’s population abruptly disappears without explanation, the world struggles to understand just what they’re supposed to do about it. The drama series The Leftovers is the story of the people who didn’t make the cut.

constellations_other.name: The world's end
constellations_other.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

links.description: Watchmen was created by Damon Lindelof, who along with Tom Perrotta, also created The Leftovers, based on Perrotta’s novel. Dealing with a rapture like event that sees millions of people around the world disappear, it also uses fantasy to explore grounded themes like grief and existentialism.
